title: HRV-Based Training Modification Protocols
content:
**HRV Fundamentals**

Heart Rate Variability measures beat-to-beat variation in heart rhythm, reflecting autonomic nervous system balance. Higher HRV generally indicates parasympathetic dominance (rest and digest), while lower HRV indicates sympathetic dominance (fight or flight).

**Measurement Protocol**

*Standardization is Critical:*
- Same time daily (within 30-minute window)
- Same position (supine recommended, or seated if always seated)
- Same duration (minimum 2-3 minutes, ideally 5 minutes)
- Before caffeine, significant movement, or stress
- Morning upon waking is gold standard
- Empty bladder (full bladder affects readings)

*Devices:*
- Chest strap (Polar H10, Garmin HRM-Pro): Most accurate
- Wrist devices: Acceptable for trends, less accurate day-to-day
- Ring devices (Oura, etc.): Good for overnight average
- Apps: HRV4Training, Elite HRV, Oura—each has slightly different algorithms

**Interpreting HRV Data**

*Baseline Establishment:*
- Minimum 2 weeks of consistent measurement to establish personal baseline
- 7-day rolling average is more meaningful than single readings
- Individual variation is huge (RMSSD 20-150+ ms all 'normal')
- Compare to YOUR baseline, not population norms

*Key Metrics:*
- RMSSD: Most commonly used, reflects parasympathetic activity
- HRV4Training's rMSSD: Normalized, comparable across apps
- Oura's HRV: Overnight average, different interpretation
- LF/HF ratio: Less reliable than RMSSD for training decisions

**Decision Protocols Based on HRV**

*Daily HRV vs 7-Day Baseline:*

HRV within normal range (±0.5 SD or within ~10%):
- Train as planned
- Body responding normally to training

HRV moderately below baseline (10-20% below, or 0.5-1.0 SD):
- Consider reducing planned intensity
- Swap intervals for tempo or tempo for easy
- If intervals planned, reduce volume or add extra recovery
- Ask: 'How do I feel?' If also feeling tired, definitely back off

HRV significantly below baseline (>20% below, or >1.0 SD):
- Strong signal for recovery day
- Convert planned workout to easy or rest
- Check for other factors: poor sleep, illness onset, high stress
- If persists 2-3 days: Consider recovery block

HRV above baseline (>1.0 SD above normal):
- Usually positive: well recovered, adaptation occurring
- Occasionally: Parasympathetic saturation (after very hard block)
- Green light for quality training

*Pattern Recognition:*

Gradually declining HRV trend over 1-2 weeks:
- Accumulated fatigue
- May need recovery week sooner than planned
- Review recent training load (ACWR)

Sudden HRV spike (unusually high):
- Often precedes illness by 24-48 hours
- Monitor for other symptoms
- Consider preventive rest day

Low HRV with elevated resting HR:
- Strong overtraining signal
- Possible illness onset
- Prioritize sleep, nutrition, stress reduction

**HRV-Guided Training Modifications**

*Example Decision Tree:*

Planned: Threshold intervals (2×20 min)
HRV: 15% below baseline
Resting HR: Normal
Subjective feel: 'Legs heavy but okay'

Decision: Modify to sweet spot (2×20 min at 88-90% FTP instead of 95-100%)
Rationale: Get quality work without digging deeper into recovery debt

*Example Decision Tree:*

Planned: Long run (18 miles)
HRV: 25% below baseline
Resting HR: Elevated 5 bpm
Subjective: 'Tired, didn't sleep well'

Decision: Easy 45-minute run or complete rest
Rationale: Multiple signals pointing to need for recovery

**Limitations of HRV**

- Not predictive of performance on any single day
- Individual response varies significantly
- Some athletes are 'non-responders' to HRV tracking
- Affected by: alcohol, travel, stress, caffeine, supplements
- Should not override race-day decisions
- One data point among many; combine with subjective feel, resting HR, sleep quality

title: Sleep Science and Optimization for Athletes
content:
**Why Sleep is the #1 Recovery Tool**

*Physiological Processes During Sleep:*
- Growth hormone release peaks in first half of night (deep sleep)
- Protein synthesis and muscle repair accelerated
- Glycogen replenishment enhanced
- Neural pathway consolidation (skill learning)
- Immune function restoration
- Hormonal balance restoration (testosterone, cortisol)
- Memory consolidation including motor patterns

*Performance Impact of Sleep Restriction:*
- <6 hours: Significant performance decrement (Mah et al., 2011)
- Reaction time worse (equivalent to 0.1% BAC after 24hr no sleep)
- Reduced time to exhaustion
- Impaired glycogen storage
- Elevated injury risk (1.7× higher with <8 hours)
- Immune suppression (3× more likely to get sick <7 hours)

**Sleep Architecture for Athletes**

*Sleep Stages:*
- N1 (Light): 5-10% - Transition, easily awakened
- N2 (Light): 45-55% - Body temperature drops, HR slows
- N3 (Deep/SWS): 15-25% - Physical restoration, GH release
- REM: 20-25% - Mental restoration, skill consolidation

*Optimal Distribution:*
- Deep sleep: Target 60-90+ minutes (first 3-4 hours critical)
- REM: Target 90-120 minutes (accumulates in second half of night)
- Awake time: <30 minutes total
- Sleep efficiency: >85%

**Evidence-Based Sleep Optimization**

*Sleep Duration:*
- Most athletes: 7.5-9 hours
- Heavy training phases: 8-10 hours
- Sleep extension studies show performance gains with 9-10 hours (Mah)
- Individual variation: Some need 7, some need 9+
- Monitor: Waking without alarm feeling refreshed = enough

*Circadian Optimization:*
- Consistent bed/wake times (±30 min) including weekends
- Light exposure: Bright light within 30 min of waking
- Light avoidance: Dim lights 2 hours before bed
- Screen reduction: Blue light blocking if screens necessary
- Temperature: 65-68°F (18-20°C) bedroom temperature
- Cool down: Core temperature drop triggers sleep

*Sleep Hygiene Protocol:*

2-3 Hours Before Bed:
- No caffeine after 2pm (or 8-10 hours before bed)
- Finish eating large meals
- Complete high-intensity exercise

1 Hour Before Bed:
- Dim lighting in home
- Start wind-down routine
- No work emails or stressful content
- Consider: Reading, light stretching, journaling

30 Minutes Before Bed:
- Blue light blocking or screens off
- Cool shower (paradoxically helps cool core)
- Relaxation techniques if helpful

Bedroom Environment:
- Dark: Blackout curtains, cover LEDs
- Cool: 65-68°F
- Quiet: Earplugs or white noise if needed
- Comfortable: Quality mattress, pillows

**Sleep Supplementation**

*Evidence-Supported:*
- Magnesium (200-400mg glycinate or citrate): Modest sleep benefit, safe
- Tart cherry juice (8oz, 2x daily): Contains natural melatonin, reduces inflammation
- Melatonin (0.5-3mg, 30-60 min before bed): Helps with timing, not sedation; lower doses often more effective

*Use with Caution:*
- Valerian: Mixed evidence
- CBD: Limited research, may help some
- Alcohol: Disrupts sleep architecture despite sedative effect

**Napping Protocol**

*When Naps Help:*
- Sleep debt accumulation
- Heavy training phase
- Before evening competition
- After travel across time zones

*Optimal Nap Structure:*
- Power nap: 15-20 min (avoid deep sleep)
- Full cycle: 90 min (complete sleep cycle)
- Timing: Before 3pm to avoid nighttime disruption
- Environment: Dark, quiet, comfortable

**Travel and Sleep**

*Jet Lag Mitigation:*
- Pre-adapt: Shift sleep 1 hour/day toward destination time
- Light exposure: Match to destination timing
- Melatonin: Take at destination bedtime
- Hydration: Avoid alcohol, caffeine during flight
- First day at destination: Light exercise, outdoor light exposure
- Adaptation rate: ~1 day per hour of time zone change

*Race-Week Sleep:*
- Sleep bank: Extra 30-60 min/night in week before key race
- Night before race: Accept some poor sleep; it won't hurt you
- Multiple nights before: More important than night before

title: Overtraining Syndrome: Detection, Prevention, and Recovery
content:
**The Overtraining Continuum**

*Stage 1: Functional Overreaching (FOR)*
- What: Short-term performance decline with training stress
- Duration: Days to 1-2 weeks
- Recovery: Rest days to 1 week
- Status: Normal and often desired part of training
- Outcome: Supercompensation when recovered

*Stage 2: Non-Functional Overreaching (NFOR)*
- What: Extended performance decline, early warning signs
- Duration: 2-6 weeks to recover
- Symptoms: Persistent fatigue, mood changes, sleep disruption
- Status: Warning zone—intervention needed
- Outcome: Full recovery possible with appropriate rest

*Stage 3: Overtraining Syndrome (OTS)*
- What: Severe, persistent performance decline and systemic issues
- Duration: Months to recover (sometimes 6-12+ months)
- Symptoms: Systemic exhaustion, hormonal disruption, depression
- Status: Serious condition requiring medical evaluation
- Outcome: Full recovery possible but prolonged; some athletes never fully return

**Comprehensive Symptom Checklist**

*Performance Markers:*
- [ ] Declining performance despite maintained/increased training
- [ ] Unable to complete usual workouts
- [ ] Decreased power/pace at same HR
- [ ] Increased perceived effort for same output
- [ ] Poor response to tapering
- [ ] Plateau or regression in fitness markers

*Physiological Markers:*
- [ ] Elevated resting heart rate (>5 bpm consistently)
- [ ] Decreased HRV (>15-20% below baseline consistently)
- [ ] Heart rate fails to rise appropriately during exercise (parasympathetic OTS)
- [ ] Excessive HR response to exercise (sympathetic OTS)
- [ ] Prolonged recovery HR after exercise
- [ ] Frequent illness/infection (compromised immune system)
- [ ] Persistent muscle soreness
- [ ] Unexplained weight loss
- [ ] Changes in appetite (increased or decreased)
- [ ] Sleep disturbances despite fatigue
- [ ] Menstrual irregularity (female athletes)
- [ ] Decreased libido

*Psychological Markers:*
- [ ] Persistent fatigue not relieved by sleep
- [ ] Depression or mood swings
- [ ] Irritability
- [ ] Loss of motivation for training
- [ ] Loss of competitive drive
- [ ] Increased anxiety
- [ ] Difficulty concentrating
- [ ] Apathy toward activities once enjoyed

**Risk Factor Assessment**

*Training Factors:*
- Rapid training load increase (ACWR >1.5)
- Monotonous training (same workouts repeatedly)
- Excessive high-intensity work (>20-25% of total)
- Insufficient recovery between hard sessions
- Racing too frequently
- Training through illness

*Lifestyle Factors:*
- Inadequate sleep (<7 hours consistently)
- High life stress (work, relationships, financial)
- Poor nutrition (caloric deficit, low carbs)
- Inadequate hydration
- Travel fatigue and jet lag
- Major life changes

*Individual Susceptibility:*
- Previous history of overtraining
- Perfectionist personality type
- High intrinsic motivation (athletes push through warning signs)
- Young athletes (pressure to perform)
- Masters athletes (reduced recovery capacity)

**Prevention Protocol**

*Training Management:*
- Follow periodized plan with built-in recovery weeks
- Monitor ACWR (keep 0.8-1.3)
- Maximum CTL increase: 5-7 points/week
- 80/20 intensity distribution
- Respect easy days (keep them easy)
- Recovery weeks every 3-4 weeks (50-60% volume)

*Monitoring System:*
- Daily: Subjective wellness score (1-10), sleep quality, resting HR
- Weekly: HRV trends, training load review
- Monthly: Performance testing, blood work if indicated
- Ongoing: Body weight, menstrual cycle (female athletes)

*Red Flag Response:*
- 1 symptom for 1-2 days: Note, monitor closely
- 2-3 symptoms or persisting 3+ days: Reduce training load
- Multiple symptoms persisting 1+ week: Recovery block (5-10 days easy)
- Severe or prolonged symptoms: Medical evaluation

**Recovery from Overtraining**

*Mild Overreaching (FOR):*
- Rest: 2-5 days complete rest or very easy activity
- Sleep: Prioritize 8-10 hours
- Nutrition: Ensure caloric adequacy, increase carbs
- Return: Gradual, start at 50-60% normal load

*Moderate Overreaching (NFOR):*
- Rest: 1-3 weeks significantly reduced training or complete rest
- Focus: Sleep, nutrition, stress reduction
- Medical: Consider blood work (ferritin, thyroid, cortisol)
- Return: Very gradual over 2-4 weeks, listen to body
- Volume first, intensity last when returning

*Overtraining Syndrome (OTS):*
- Rest: Weeks to months of complete rest from structured training
- Medical: Full evaluation, hormone panels, psychological support
- Focus: Overall health, not athletics
- Activities: Only enjoyable, non-structured movement
- Return: May take 3-12 months; requires patience
- Supervision: Work with sports medicine professional

**Return-to-Training Protocol Post-OTS**

Weeks 1-2:
- Very light activity only (walking, easy swimming)
- Duration: 20-30 min maximum
- Frequency: 3-4 days/week
- Monitor: All symptoms, especially fatigue next day

Weeks 3-4:
- Light aerobic activity
- Duration: 30-45 min
- Intensity: Zone 1 only (truly conversational)
- Frequency: 4-5 days/week
- Check: If any symptom return, back off

Weeks 5-8:
- Gradual volume increase
- Duration building toward normal
- Intensity: Zone 1-2 only, no intervals
- Frequency: Normal
- Check: Performance should be improving; if not, reassess

Weeks 9+:
- Gradual intensity reintroduction
- Start with tempo, then threshold, then VO2max
- Volume: 70-80% of previous peak initially
- Ongoing monitoring of symptoms

title: Active Recovery and Recovery Modalities
content:
**Active vs Passive Recovery**

Active recovery involves low-intensity movement that promotes blood flow without adding training stress. Research supports active recovery for faster lactate clearance and reduced perceived fatigue, though effects on actual adaptation are modest.

**Active Recovery Guidelines**

*Intensity Parameters:*
- Heart rate: <65% max HR (ideally <60%)
- Power: <55% FTP
- Pace: 2+ min/mile slower than threshold
- RPE: 2-3/10 maximum
- Conversation: Full sentences, no effort

*Duration:*
- Minimum: 15-20 minutes (for blood flow benefit)
- Maximum: 45-60 minutes (beyond this adds fatigue)
- Sweet spot: 20-40 minutes

*Timing:*
- Same day after hard workout: 2-4 hours post, gentle spin/swim
- Day after hard workout: Morning active recovery session
- Between two-a-days: Very easy movement between sessions

**Activity Selection**

*Ideal for Active Recovery:*
- Easy cycling/spinning (no resistance)
- Swimming (non-taxing, low-intensity)
- Pool running (zero impact)
- Walking
- Gentle yoga or stretching
- Light hiking (flat terrain)
- Elliptical (low resistance)

*Less Ideal (Still Valid):*
- Easy running (impact still present)
- Rowing (can be difficult to keep easy)
- Cross-country skiing (full body demand)

**Recovery Modalities: Evidence Review**

*Tier 1: Strong Evidence*

Sleep:
- Most powerful recovery tool
- Irreplaceable by any other modality
- See dedicated sleep section

Nutrition:
- Adequate calories prevent recovery deficits
- Protein timing (20-40g post-workout) supports repair
- Carbohydrate replenishment for glycogen
- Hydration for all physiological processes

*Tier 2: Moderate Evidence*

Compression Garments:
- Mechanism: Improved venous return, reduced swelling
- Evidence: Modest benefit for perceived recovery, muscle soreness
- Protocol: Wear for 2-4 hours post-exercise or overnight
- Best use: After long/hard sessions, during travel

Cold Water Immersion (CWI):
- Mechanism: Vasoconstriction, reduced inflammation, analgesic
- Evidence: Reduces muscle soreness (DOMS), may impair hypertrophy adaptation
- Protocol: 10-15 min at 10-15°C (50-59°F)
- Best use: Competition phase when adaptation matters less than readiness
- Caution: May blunt training adaptation; don't use after every session

Massage:
- Mechanism: Blood flow, fascial release, parasympathetic activation
- Evidence: Reduces DOMS, improves perceived recovery
- Frequency: Weekly or as needed/affordable
- Timing: Day after hard training or 2+ days before competition

*Tier 3: Limited/Mixed Evidence*

Foam Rolling:
- Mechanism: Myofascial release, increased blood flow
- Evidence: Modest reduction in DOMS, improved range of motion
- Protocol: 1-2 minutes per muscle group, moderate pressure
- Best use: Post-workout or before bed
- Note: Doesn't replace stretching or proper recovery

Pneumatic Compression (NormaTec, etc.):
- Mechanism: Sequential compression, lymphatic drainage
- Evidence: Mixed; may reduce perceived fatigue
- Protocol: 20-30 minutes at moderate pressure
- Best use: Post-long sessions, travel recovery

Contrast Therapy (Hot/Cold Alternating):
- Mechanism: Vascular 'pumping' from alternating
- Evidence: Limited; may be psychological
- Protocol: 1-2 min cold, 3-4 min warm, repeat 3-4 cycles
- Ending: Cold for inflammation, warm for relaxation

Sauna/Heat Therapy:
- Mechanism: Heat shock proteins, plasma volume expansion
- Evidence: Benefits for cardiovascular adaptation, not acute recovery
- Protocol: 15-30 min at 80-100°C post-workout
- Caution: Dehydration risk; rehydrate aggressively
- Note: Different purpose than recovery (more adaptation/heat acclimation)

*Tier 4: Minimal/No Evidence*

- Cupping: No evidence beyond placebo
- TENS/EMS for recovery: Limited evidence
- Cryotherapy chambers: Similar to CWI but expensive, less researched
- 'Detox' products: No scientific basis

**Recovery Week Protocol**

*Timing:* Every 3-4 weeks during build, or when needed based on symptoms

*Structure:*
- Volume: 50-65% of normal week
- Intensity: Remove hard sessions or drastically reduce
- Frequency: Can maintain or slightly reduce
- Include: Extra sleep, mobility work, lifestyle enjoyment

*What to Expect:*
- Day 1-2: May feel surprisingly flat or tired
- Day 3-4: Body realizes it's recovering
- Day 5-7: Energy returning, readiness improving
- Return: Ready for productive training

**Weekly Recovery Integration Example**

Hard Training Week Structure:
- Monday: Rest or active recovery (30 min easy spin)
- Tuesday: Quality session
- Wednesday: Moderate volume, lower intensity + mobility
- Thursday: Quality session
- Friday: Rest or active recovery + massage
- Saturday: Long session
- Sunday: Easy session or rest

Prioritize: 2 complete rest or active recovery days minimum
Avoid: Stacking hard sessions without recovery between

title: Stress Management and Training Load Integration
content:
**The Cumulative Stress Model**

The body has a finite recovery capacity that must accommodate ALL stressors:

*Training Stress:*
- Volume and intensity of workouts
- Training frequency
- Competition demands
- Travel for training/racing

*Life Stress:*
- Work demands and deadlines
- Financial pressure
- Relationship issues
- Family responsibilities
- Major life changes (move, job change, etc.)

*Physical Stress:*
- Poor sleep
- Illness or injury
- Inadequate nutrition
- Environmental factors (heat, altitude, pollution)

*The Key Insight:* Your body doesn't distinguish between sources. A hard interval session + work deadline + poor sleep = potentially overwhelming stress load, even if any single factor would be manageable alone.

**Quantifying Life Stress**

*Daily Stress Scoring (1-10):*
- 1-3: Low stress day (routine, manageable)
- 4-6: Moderate stress (some challenges but handling)
- 7-8: High stress (significant demands, feeling strain)
- 9-10: Extreme stress (crisis level, barely coping)

*Training Modification Guidelines:*

Life Stress 1-4:
- Train as planned
- Full capacity for adaptation
- Can push appropriately

Life Stress 5-6:
- Train as planned but monitor closely
- Be willing to modify if session feels harder than expected
- Prioritize sleep

Life Stress 7-8:
- Reduce training intensity by one level (intervals → tempo, tempo → easy)
- Reduce volume by 20-30%
- Focus on stress-reducing activities (easy aerobic, yoga, walking)
- This is not weakness; this is smart training

Life Stress 9-10:
- Consider complete rest or very easy movement only
- Training may do more harm than good
- Focus on the stressor, not fitness
- Fitness loss is minimal; injury/burnout risk is high

**Stress Management Techniques**

*Acute Stress Reduction (In-the-Moment):*

Physiological Sigh (Huberman):
- Double inhale through nose (fill lungs, then sip more)
- Long exhale through mouth
- Repeat 3-5 times
- Activates parasympathetic nervous system

Box Breathing:
- Inhale 4 seconds
- Hold 4 seconds
- Exhale 4 seconds
- Hold 4 seconds
- Repeat 4+ cycles

5-4-3-2-1 Grounding:
- 5 things you can see
- 4 things you can touch
- 3 things you can hear
- 2 things you can smell
- 1 thing you can taste

*Daily Stress Management Practices:*

Morning Routine (10-15 min):
- Avoid phone for first 30 min
- Light exposure (go outside or bright light)
- Brief movement or stretching
- Intention setting or journaling

Midday Reset (5-10 min):
- Step away from work
- Walk outside if possible
- Brief breathing exercise
- Disconnect from screens

Evening Wind-Down (30-60 min before bed):
- Dim lights
- Screen-free activities
- Relaxation routine
- Gratitude or reflection practice

*Weekly Stress Management:*
- One completely unstructured day (no training plan, no obligations)
- Social connection (non-training related)
- Nature exposure (even 20 min in green space reduces cortisol)
- Hobby or activity unrelated to sport

**Training as Stress Relief vs Stress Addition**

*When Training Reduces Stress:*
- Easy, enjoyable sessions
- Social training with friends
- Outdoor sessions in nature
- Sessions where you feel strong and capable
- Running/cycling as 'moving meditation'

*When Training Adds Stress:*
- High-intensity when already exhausted
- Training that feels like obligation
- Sessions you're dreading
- Performance anxiety about workouts
- Squeezing training into already packed schedule

*The Litmus Test:*
Ask yourself before training: 'Will this workout leave me feeling better or worse overall (not just physically)?'

**Periodizing Around Life Demands**

*Proactive Planning:*
- Know your busy seasons at work
- Plan recovery weeks around high-stress periods
- Schedule A-races during lower life-stress periods if possible
- Build buffer into training plan for unexpected stress

*Reactive Adjustment:*
- Permission to modify plan without guilt
- The training plan serves you, not vice versa
- Missed workouts due to life stress ≠ failure
- Consistency over months > perfection in any week

**Red Flags: Stress Overload**

- Dreading all workouts (not just hard ones)
- Training feels like punishment
- Persistent irritability and short temper
- Relationship problems attributed to training demands
- Work performance declining
- Unable to be present in non-training life
- Using training to 'escape' rather than enhance life

*If Multiple Red Flags Present:*
- Training is currently subtracting from life quality
- Take extended break (1-2 weeks minimum)
- Reassess priorities and training role
- Consider working with sports psychologist
- Return with healthier relationship to training

title: Periodized Recovery and Supercompensation
content:
**Understanding Supercompensation**

*The Stress-Adaptation Cycle:*
1. Training stimulus (stress)
2. Fatigue and temporary performance decrease
3. Recovery period
4. Supercompensation (fitness above baseline)
5. Detraining (if no new stimulus) or new stimulus (continued adaptation)

*Critical Timing:*
- Next workout too soon: Inadequate recovery, cumulative fatigue
- Next workout at right time: Build on supercompensation, progressive overload
- Next workout too late: Supercompensation fades, opportunity missed

*Practical Application:*
- Time between hard sessions varies by individual and workout type
- General guideline: 48-72 hours between hard sessions
- May need more as athlete ages or during high life stress

**Recovery Timelines by Session Type**

*Very Easy Session (Zone 1, short):*
- Recovery time: 12-24 hours
- Can train hard the next day
- Example: 30-min recovery spin, easy swim

*Moderate Aerobic (Zone 2, long):*
- Recovery time: 24-36 hours
- Example: 90-min endurance ride, long easy run
- May need easy day following, can train hard in 2 days

*Tempo/Sweet Spot Session:*
- Recovery time: 36-48 hours
- Example: 2×20min sweet spot, tempo run
- Easy day following recommended

*Threshold Session:*
- Recovery time: 48-72 hours
- Example: 2×20min at FTP, threshold intervals
- Should not do another hard session for 2 days minimum

*VO2max Session:*
- Recovery time: 48-72 hours
- High neuromuscular and cardiovascular demand
- Example: 5×4min at 105-115% FTP
- Quality suffers if done too frequently

*Race or Race-Simulation:*
- Recovery time: 72-96+ hours depending on duration and intensity
- Full recovery may take 1-2 weeks for major race
- Avoid quality training for several days after

*Long Endurance Session (3+ hours):*
- Recovery time: 48-72 hours
- Glycogen depletion, significant muscle damage
- Example: Long ride, marathon-pace long run
- Next day should be rest or very easy

**Microcycle Recovery Patterns**

*Classic Pattern (3:1 loading):*
- Week 1: 100% planned load
- Week 2: 105-110% planned load
- Week 3: 110-115% planned load
- Week 4: 50-60% (recovery week)

*Aggressive Pattern (2:1 loading):*
- Weeks 1-2: Progressive loading
- Week 3: Recovery
- Best for: Masters athletes, high life stress, injury-prone

*Conservative Pattern (4:1 loading):*
- Weeks 1-4: Progressive loading
- Week 5: Recovery
- Best for: Young athletes, low life stress, high recovery capacity

**Recovery Week Prescription**

*Volume:* 50-65% of normal
*Intensity:* Remove or drastically reduce hard sessions
*Structure:*

Example Recovery Week (normally training 10 hrs):
- Monday: Rest
- Tuesday: 45 min easy + 4 strides (not intervals)
- Wednesday: 60 min Zone 2 only
- Thursday: Rest or 30 min easy
- Friday: 45 min with 10 min tempo (just a touch)
- Saturday: 90 min easy (vs normal 3 hr long)
- Sunday: 45 min easy

*What to Add:*
- Extra sleep (30-60 min more per night)
- Mobility and flexibility work
- Massage or other recovery modalities
- Social, non-training activities
- Catch up on life demands

*What to Expect:*
- Days 1-2: May feel flat, sluggish, 'taper tantrum'
- Days 3-4: Body realizes it's recovering
- Days 5-7: Energy returning, motivation building
- Post-recovery week: Ready for productive training

**Mesocycle Recovery (Training Blocks)**

*After Base Block (12-16 weeks):*
- Recovery: 1 full recovery week
- May feel loss of urgency; this is normal
- Prepare mentally for build phase intensity

*After Build Block (6-8 weeks):*
- Recovery: 1 week before competition phase
- Or transition directly into taper for A-race

*After Race/Competition Block:*
- Short races (5K-half marathon): 3-7 days recovery
- Marathon: 2-3 weeks very easy before structured training
- Ironman: 3-4 weeks recovery minimum; 6-8 weeks common
- Stage race/heavy competition block: 1-2 weeks easy

**Deload vs Recovery Week**

*Deload Week:*
- Reduced volume (60-70%)
- Maintains some intensity
- Purpose: Absorb fitness before key workout or test
- Duration: 3-5 days typically

*Recovery Week:*
- Significantly reduced volume (50-60%)
- Minimal or no intensity
- Purpose: Full systemic recovery, mental break
- Duration: 5-7 days

*When to Use Each:*
- Deload: Before FTP test, before key race simulation, mid-block refresh
- Recovery: End of training block, after A-race, when showing fatigue signs
